title: How to Maintain a Curly Weave

steps.headline: Use your fingers to comb through your hair if your curls are very tight.
steps.description: If your weave has super tight curls, using a comb or brush might not work. Instead, you can use your fingers to detangle any knots or snarls that you find. Make sure your hair is dry, and try not to rip or pull your hair too much. Finger detangling takes more time than brushing with a tool. Set aside at least 30 minutes if you choose to do this.

steps.headline: Use a wide-toothed comb or soft-bristled brush to comb your weave.
steps.description: Normal hair brushes are too fine for curly hair, and they can damage the curl pattern by breaking it apart too much. Get a wide-toothed comb or a soft-bristled brush that is made specifically for curly hair to brush out your weave. You can buy these tools at most beauty supply stores.

steps.headline: Start brushing from the bottom and work your way toward your scalp.
steps.description: If you are using a comb, brush, or your fingers, start from the bottom of your weave and work your way to the top. Make sure that you aren’t brushing too hard or pulling your hair at all, as this can damage your weave.Tip: Detangle your weave while it is wet to cause less damage to your hair.

steps.headline: Detangle specific knots one at a time.
steps.description: Instead of brushing out all of your hair, you can brush out specific knots as you see them. Use a wide-toothed comb or your fingers to gently tease apart tangles while your hair is wet. If your weave has a tangle that is particularly challenging to get out, try using the pointed end of a pick to tease apart the hair before combing or brushing it.

steps.headline: Wash your weave with a sulfate-free shampoo once a week.
steps.description: The natural oils from your scalp will start to build up on your weave over time. Use a sulfate-free shampoo once a week to thoroughly wash your weave. If you have oily or greasy skin, you may have to wash your weave more often than once a week.

steps.headline: Apply conditioner to your hair once a day.
steps.description: The number one thing that curly weaves need is moisture. Use a silicone and sulfate-free conditioner once a day on your hair while it is wet in the shower. Let it sit for 2 to 3 minutes and then rinse it out thoroughly.Tip: If you have a buildup of oil on your scalp, you can use your conditioner to massage it away in the shower and then rinse it out of your hair.

steps.headline: Let your weave dry naturally to enhance the curls.
steps.description: Air drying is the best way for your weave to form its natural curl pattern. Try to avoid using heat tools, like hairdryers, on your weave. Instead, let it dry naturally for a few hours. If you need your hair dried faster, you can attach a diffuser to your hairdryer. Diffusers spread out the heat from the dryer and make it less damaging to your curls.

steps.headline: Wrap your hair in a silk bonnet to protect your curls.
steps.description: Tie your hair back in a loose ponytail with a scrunchie or pile your hair on top of your head. Then, put a silk scarf or bonnet on over your hair. Make sure that no curls poke out of the bonnet. This will keep your curls intact while you lay on them to sleep.Tip: If your hair is particularly long, look for an elongated bonnet that will hold all of your hair.

steps.headline: Put a satin pillowcase on your pillow.
steps.description: Satin pillowcases help keep your curls intact while you sleep on them because they don’t bunch up and create creases on your pillow. Buy a satin pillowcase from a beauty supply store and sleep with it on your pillow instead of a cotton one. Satin pillowcases also reduce the number of pillow creases you get on your skin when you wake up.

steps.headline: Put your hair up in a loose bun.
steps.description: To keep your curls preserved without any extra tools, simply tie your hair up in a loose bun at the top of your head with a scrunchie. Don’t tie it too tight, or it will leave creases in your hair. Depending on the thickness of your weave, loop your scrunchie around your hair 2 to 3 times before you go to sleep. This method usually works the best for tight curls.

steps.headline: Spray your hair with water in the morning to refresh your curls.
steps.description: If your curls are looking flat from sleeping on them, you can spritz them with a small amount of water to revive them. Put room temperature water in a spray bottle and spray your hair in the areas that need it. Let your hair air dry.Tip: You can mix in a pea-sized amount of conditioner to your water if your hair is frizzy.

steps.headline: Add a palmful of mousse to wet hair for defined curls.
steps.description: If you want your weave to have more defined curls, you can apply mousse to your hair while it is damp. Get a half-dollar sized amount in your palm and spread it onto your curls, starting from your scalp and working your way downward. Add more mousse as you need it for thicker hair. You can use any type of curl defining mousse, as long as it is silicone and sulfate-free.

steps.headline: Slick down your baby hairs in a wavy pattern to emphasize your curls.
steps.description: If your weave has baby hairs, you can slick them down with gel in a sweeping motion to compliment your curls. Use a fine-tooth comb or a toothbrush to smooth the hairs on your head. Then, use a pea-sized amount of gel to secure them down, using a sweeping outward motion to apply the gel. Only slick down the wispy hairs that are on the front of the weave. Anything more will look too heavy.
